oai_dc:dc.dc:description: PETITION HOOPER TO NAME WOMAN JUDGE - Mrs. L. Crozier French, well known among Memphis club women, social workers and equal suffrage advocates has become a candidate for judge of the juvenile court at Knoxville. She is the first woman in the state to publicly aspire to such an office. A number of Memphis women have written letters supporting her Candida cy. Mrs. French has many close friends here. She was a prominent figure in the convention of the Ten- nessee Mothers' congress in Memphis last year, and this year the congress has indorsed (sic.) a bill enabling women to become members of school boards and juvenile court judges. "No policemen nor lawyers are allowed in a juvenile court of the right character." declares a pitition (sic.) to Gov. Hooper which has found many Mem- phis signers, and seeking the appoint- ment of Mrs. French to the place. "Visitors should be admitted only by tickets issued by the judge. The whole idea is to remove the children as far as possible from the suspicion of crime, and to keep as secret as possible the delinquencies of children, to the end that reformation may be accomplished without the hardening processes that might ordinarily follow the ordinary trials in other courts. "It was happened that this idea has not obtained, with some of the men who have been placed at the head of juvenile courts in several of our cities and that in consequence no great im- provement has been made in regard to the condition of children over the old mode of trial. No one who has not served an apprenticeship to social service is fitted for the place of juvenile judge."—Memphis News Scimitar.
